nodes.bodyText: 443 isn't really MQTT, but more commonly HTTPS.

Based on the SDK, either port can be possibly used https://github.com/aws/aws-iot-device-sdk-java-v2/blob/28a82838a64ef61ca5235f0bb5b7824d8157bf87/sdk/src/main/java/software/amazon/awssdk/iot/AwsIotMqttConnectionBuilder.java#L65-L72 We don't hardcode the port in Deployment Service

These are server ports, modify the name to indicate that. 443 is used in MQTT over websockets. Usually those are meant to be used when we need MQTT from browsers. We should not be using this but since we are not specifying the port, and choice of port depends if the platform has ALPN enabled or not, I would still keep it.
Why not make this agnostic to the ports? Pass the ports in as varargs. Since the other methods are specific to what ports are enabled/disabled.
This is taking down the entire network, not the specific ports, right? Do we have a better option on mac to limit specific ports?
I tried a few ways but couldn't find another clean and simple solution. Packet filtering does not apply to established connections on Mac.

Is en0 the only interface through which communication was happening on the machines we are testing?
Ideally we can find out which interface was being used and put that as down. You may use 'route -n get <mqtt_endpoint> | grep interface'  to get information about which interface is being used, but this may need to be done until all interfaces are blocked. I would say spend some time to see if it is quick, otherwise may not be worth spending time on this.

Did you try the pf firewall settings? https://apple.stackexchange.com/a/230556
If this can't block ongoing connections, then you could potentially block the port with pf, then take down the whole network and bring it back up.
Yes. Tried the PF firewall settings and doesn't affect ongoing connections. So this current impl takes down the network and bring it back up.

@abanthiy I did some testing. en0 is a hardware interface (usually Ethernet and WiFi). When I'm on VPN, It's actually using interface utun1. Though a rare case, the interface might change during the test. I feel it might be more stable to use the hardware interface.
ok
this interface can just be Iterable.
Whenever we change properties like this, we should undo it in the after, so that it doens't have hard to debug effects.
If we do not want to cache we can set it to 0 instead of setting it to 10?

Do we really need both this test and the online scenario? Surely if this one works, then so would the online version. While obviously this gives us even better assurance, I don't want us to have duplicate test cases so early on which may just be wasting time.

It's a valid concern. The actual behaviors from the IoT cloud are slightly different. In the online case, I saw more duplicate notifications for the first job, while in the offline case, we just got 1 notification per job most of the case. I'll include @abanthiy here as well to decide if we should keep both cases.

These two tests are basically same, so no point keeping them both. I would keep the offline one here (since we already test online one in the other test). When we add tests for cancellation, that time we should cover different scenario for multiple jobs and device is online.
Discussed offline. I'm going to keep both tests cases with more inline comments to explain the reason.
I would prefer if this method just updates the kernel config and takes ThingInfo as an input parameter.   Would also rename the method to injectDeploymentConfigurationToKernel
In Utils, can we split this into two methods, one for provisioning the device (create Iot thing, certs, groups, add the device to group) and other for updating the deployment config in kernel.
will do
You can make these constants public and use them here instead - https://github.com/aws/aws-greengrass-kernel/blob/master/src/main/java/com/aws/iot/evergreen/deployment/DeploymentService.java#L58

Have we thought about making deloymentDetails a strongly typed POJO?

You can make these constants public and use them here instead - https://github.com/aws/aws-greengrass-kernel/blob/master/src/main/java/com/aws/iot/evergreen/deployment/DeploymentService.java#L58
@leaf94 good idea! I'll leave that change to future iterations though, until deloymentDetails is finalized.
What is stopping from creating a Thing group and putting that as a target?

Why do we need to check count of the latch here? Do we sometimes get this for both inprogress and complete updates?
Also, we need to check for timeout case as well, which is handled here - https://github.com/aws/aws-greengrass-kernel/blob/master/src/main/java/com/aws/iot/evergreen/deployment/DeploymentService.java#L358
I would prefer making these log strings as constants in the DeploymentService and use those constants here. Otherwise this is fragile.
Will do.
Similar as before, whats missing from creating the group and adding that as target?
If this class is meant to create different deployment documents then it should be named as DeploymentDocumentCreationHelper. Also it can be pulled out and used in both the test classes?
In addition to previous comment, I would not create the Iot Job in this method and only create the deployment document.
Accept a list of target packages?
For the SomeService package, should this be FINISHED or RUNNING? You can put the expected state in the Helper class you are creating.
All these test packages have a run block that executes very fast and end with FINISHED state.
Do you need the destination port? You can only block what is coming from the server, and the client port is random.
Yes. The commands here are only filtering the server side ports
If there are two deployments with same id but different DeploymentType, they will be treated same, which is not desired. Include deploymentType for equals comparison as well.

If there are two deployments with same id but different DeploymentType, they will be treated same, which is not desired. Include deploymentType for equals comparison as well.

What does it mean when two deployment with same id but different type?

Discussed offline. Shadow-based deployments and IoT-job based deployments are managed separately and we need to investigate further whether we can make sure the deployment ID is unique across all. Will add type to equal comparison for now.
Thanks! I should've made this into a FileUtils. It is useful!
I understand we need to do many wait in this test but can we make the timeout shorter? 10 minutes for a test to fail to too long for further maintenance...
nit cmd -> platform
When can this be null?
Root packages with requirements. This code path is not hit in usual cases but I've came across it in tests with wrong setup. So I feel it's safer to add the null check here.
isn't there an enum for this? If so, can we use that instead of the string?
Yes. I'll update this
space before =

Sorry if I am bringing this again and probably changing mind about naming, I feel DeploymentJob seems more apt name to me seeing what this class is doing. I think helper is an overloaded term and in my mind I expect only one helper object of a type in a class. But we initialize multiple helper of this type in the Test class, which does not look right to me. Replace this class name with DeploymentJob and the object names (in test class) with deploymentJob and see if it makes it more intuitive.
Discussed offline. Going with DeploymentJobHelper for now until we found a better name to describe the usage of this class.
This class needs to use the EGExtension as well.
I saw Shirley has a PR out so didn't address it here.
Switch this to EGExtension.class which includes both log and processes protection.

Will address in a separate PR right away!
UPDATE: fixed in this PR
